articles.headline: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders
articles.snippet: Representative Todd Akin said definitively Tuesday that he would not step aside. After his comments on rape, fellow Republicans, including Mitt Romney, asked him to drop out of the Missouri Senate race.
articles.abstract: Representative Todd Akin said definitively Tuesday that he would not step aside. After his comments on rape, fellow Republicans, including Mitt Romney, asked him to drop out of the Missouri Senate race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Todd Akin on Tuesday ignored a deadline to abandon Missouri’s Senate race and vowed to remain the Republican nominee in defiance of his party’s leaders, including the presidential standard-bearer, Mitt Romney.

articles.headline: ABC Sees a Contender in Jimmy Kimmel
articles.snippet: The announcement on Tuesday that Mr. Kimmel’s show will move up a half-hour sets up a direct competition with Jay Leno and David Letterman.
articles.abstract: The announcement on Tuesday that Mr. Kimmel’s show will move up a half-hour sets up a direct competition with Jay Leno and David Letterman.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2002, ABC pulled out every stop to lure David Letterman away from CBS, offering him the time period occupied by its news program “Nightline.” The network failed, and soon after inserted a new late-night host, Jimmy Kimmel, in the hour after “Nightline.”

articles.headline: American Thwarted in Quest to Build a Ski Resort in India
articles.snippet: A hotel developer wants to build India’s first Western-style ski resort in the Himalayas, but even the gods, it seems, are against him.
articles.abstract: A hotel developer wants to build India’s first Western-style ski resort in the Himalayas, but even the gods, it seems, are against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANALI, India — To John Sims, the Himalayas, with some of the finest mountain slopes in the world, seemed like the perfect place to build India’s first Western-style ski resort.

articles.headline: Rationing Health Care More Fairly
articles.snippet: The United States already rations health care, mostly by income level. With more spending cuts inevitable, the question is how to do it fairly.
articles.abstract: The United States already rations health care, mostly by income level. With more spending cuts inevitable, the question is how to do it fairly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Older adults are understandably anxious about the political sniping over the future financing of Medicare. That is precisely the intention of the presidential campaigns.

articles.headline: In Toll of 2,000, New Portrait of Afghan War
articles.snippet: As the war in Afghanistan wears on, an analysis of troop casualties reflects the effect of the 2010 troop surge and points to the growing danger from an ostensible ally.
articles.abstract: As the war in Afghanistan wears on, an analysis of troop casualties reflects the effect of the 2010 troop surge and points to the growing danger from an ostensible ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: His war was almost over. Or so Marina Buckley thought when her son Lance Cpl. Gregory T. Buckley Jr. told her that he would be returning from southern Afghanistan to his Marine Corps base in Hawaii in late August, three months early.
articles.byline: By James Dao and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Dispute Over Islands Reflects Japanese Fear of China’s Rise
articles.snippet: A chain of islands at the center of a territorial dispute has Japanese nationalists pushing their country to boldly counter the explosive growth of China and South Korea.
articles.abstract: A chain of islands at the center of a territorial dispute has Japanese nationalists pushing their country to boldly counter the explosive growth of China and South Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISHIGAKI, Japan — When the flotilla of 21 fishing boats arrived at an island chain at the center of a growing territorial dispute with China, the captains warned the dozens of activists and politicians aboard not to attempt a landing.

articles.headline: Akin Controversy Stirs Up Abortion Issue in Campaign
articles.snippet: Representative Todd Akin’s remarks on rape have focused attention on the party’s agenda on restricting abortion rights, a politically volatile topic for Mitt Romney and other candidates.
articles.abstract: Representative Todd Akin’s remarks on rape have focused attention on the party’s agenda on restricting abortion rights, a politically volatile topic for Mitt Romney and other candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As an orator, Representative Todd Akin of Missouri may stand out for his clumsiness. But as a legislator, Mr. Akin has a record on abortion that is largely indistinguishable from those of most of his Republican House colleagues, who have viewed restricting abortion rights as one of their top priorities.

articles.headline: The New Rise of a Summer Hit: Tweet It Maybe
articles.snippet: This summer’s pop hit, Carly Rae Jepsen’s cheerfully flirty “Call Me Maybe,” shows how much the hitmaking machine, and the music industry, have been upended by social media.
articles.abstract: This summer’s pop hit, Carly Rae Jepsen’s cheerfully flirty “Call Me Maybe,” shows how much the hitmaking machine, and the music industry, have been upended by social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the song of the summer would emerge each year following a pattern as predictable as the beach tides.

articles.headline: The New High-Tech Dating Technology? Meet in a Bar
articles.snippet: Data exchanged over the Internet can go only so far, so online dating services are hosting offline events to bring people together more quickly.
articles.abstract: Data exchanged over the Internet can go only so far, so online dating services are hosting offline events to bring people together more quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist.

articles.headline: Web Sites Accused of Collecting Data on Children
articles.snippet: Advocacy groups say six popular Web sites have encouraged children to provide friends’ e-mail addresses without seeking parental consent.
articles.abstract: Advocacy groups say six popular Web sites have encouraged children to provide friends’ e-mail addresses without seeking parental consent.
articles.lead_paragraph: A coalition of nearly 20 children’s advocacy, health and public interest groups plans to file complaints with the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday, asserting that some online marketing to children by McDonald’s and four other well-known companies violates a federal law protecting children’s privacy.

articles.headline: A Quick End to TARP Means a Smaller Payoff for Taxpayers
articles.snippet: The government is trying to sell its preferred stock holdings of the smaller banks, but the potential losses from the auctions could be in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The government is trying to sell its preferred stock holdings of the smaller banks, but the potential losses from the auctions could be in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quietly, the Treasury Department is engaged in another bailout of the banks. This time, it’s America’s small banks that are the lucky duckies.
